title: Anti-Money Laundering
body:
In order to protect Unilever’s reputation and to avoid criminal and legal liability, it is essential that Unilever does not become associated with any criminal activities.

You must do your part to make sure Unilever as a company does not receive the proceeds of criminal activities, as this can constitute money laundering.

It’s important to regularly review suppliers, customers and other third parties in line with our Responsible Sourcing and Business Partner Policy.

_items.text: 'OK, that makes sense. It's your business, after all. I will speak to someone and let them know it's fine to proceed'
_items.feedback_msg: No, Sarah must be vigilant when it comes to detecting possible cases of money laundering. To help Unilever avoid legal repercussions, Sarah should not agree to approve any payment into an account in the name of a different third party or into an account other than the account listed on Unilever’s master data. Instead, she should instruct the supplier that they will need to follow the standard master data process to update their data. Businesses do change their legal names and bank accounts, but our internal process and controls need to be followed to ensure the legitimacy of the request.

_items.feedback_msg: Yes! Sarah should explain how the supplier can make a legitimate and permanent change to their bank account details.

_items.text: ‘I’m sorry, I can’t pay authorise payment into an unfamiliar account, but would you accept cash?’
_items.feedback_msg: No, Sarah should not offer any alternative payment method or operate outside of the Unilever standard processes.

Everyone must ensure that risks for consumer & occupational safety and our environment are suitably assessed and managed for all new products and processes. Appropriate specifications of raw materials, products and packaging must be used and it is essential that we manage any food allergen consumer safety risks.

Unilever has committed to work with PETA as a 'Company Working for Regulatory Change' and this underpins our brands ability to use 'no animal testing' and vegan claims. title: Avoiding Conflicts of Interest
body:
Conflicts of interest can have significant negative impacts on the reputation and effectiveness of our business and our people.

Conflicts of Interest arise when you let actual, perceived or potentially personal, financial or non-financial interests affect how objective you are at work.

title: Avoiding Conflicts of Interest
body:
Specifically, a conflict of interest can occur when you:

  • Hire, manage or influence the workload, performance assessment, granting approvals or rewards of someone who you’re close with.
  • Accept, perform or have a close personal contact who holds a Public Official role with the ability to make decisions that could impact Unilever business

title: Avoiding Conflicts of Interest
body:
• Maintain a personal interest in the business of competitors or other third parties relevant to Unilever. This includes cases where you or a close personal contact provide services to competitors, or if you hold certain investments in accordance with the policy.
  • Allow non-financial interests such as personal values, beliefs, welfare and political views to take priority over Unilever’s lawful and ethical expectations.

At Unilever, we want to continue our prestigious history by maintaining high ethical values in the way we work, demonstrating integrity, respect, responsibility and innovation in all that we do each day.

We have an obligation to live our values, uphold the Code and the Code of Business Principles, without fear of retaliation.

Unilever’s Code of Business Principles shows our respect for the rights and interests of our employees, and we expect the same level of integrity in our work and the way that we do it.

title: Living the Code
body: Unilever’s Code of Business Principles (the Code), and the policies that support it (Code Policies), set out our expectations for our employees. At Unilever, the essence of ‘Living the Code’ is putting our values into practice and reiterating our commitment to doing good in the world.

title: Living the Code
body:
If you do encounter a breach or potential breach of the Code, your Line Manager is usually the right person to report potential or actual breaches to. If this is not appropriate, you may speak with one of the following:

  • Your Business Integrity Officer
  • Unilever’s confidential Code Support Line (if allowed by law), by phone or web, or
  • If asked not to report a potential breach by your line manager or another employee, you should immediately report to your Business Integrity Officer and/or the Code Support Line.

title: Living the Code
body: We also assure employees that all concerns are taken seriously and addressed quickly with discretion.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Under the supervision of the Business Integrity Officer, if a breach of the Code is reported an investigator is then appointed to look into the allegations. Decisions on whether further action is to be taken rests with the Business Integrity Committee, which is made up of the General Manager and the most senior HR, Legal, Supply Chain, Customer Development and Finance people in the country or PMU.

Ultimately, sanctions are determined using the guidelines in the BI Sanctions Framework, which include:

  • The default sanction for breaches of a Code is a final written warning
  • The default sanction can be flexed up or down depending on aggravating or mitigating circumstances which could include the seniority of the employee, whether this a first offence and the extent to which the employee co-operated with the investigation.

title:
Understanding
the Risks
body: As Unilever employees ‘Living the Code’, it is important for us to understand that anyone who raises or reports concerns and potential or actual breaches will receive support, respect, and will not experience retaliation.

title:

body: If you raise a concern regarding a Code Policy or breach of the Code, you have the ability to remain anonymous with your identity, confidential or known, depending on your preference. What’s important is that you provide as much information as possible when you raise a concern so that a full investigation can take place.

title: Anti-Bribery and Corruption
body:
At Unilever, we have zero-tolerance when it comes to bribery and corruption. We will not—directly or indirectly—offer, pay, seek or accept a payment, gift or favour to improperly influence a business outcome.

This extends to all Unilever operations regardless of local business practices and prohibits public, commercial and even internal bribery.

title: Anti-Bribery and Corruption
body:
In most countries bribery is a criminal offence and, in many cases, their laws apply to corruption happening beyond their borders.

Therefore, a breach of such laws can result in legal and financial consequences for all parties involved, and this may include Unilever and you.

title: Anti-Bribery and Corruption

_items.text: ‘If someone is demanding a payment while truly threatening my life or liberty, can I pay?’
_items.feedback_msg: In exceptional situations where employees cannot escape imminent threat to their life, liberty, or physical harm without meeting a demand for payment, such a payment may be made. What is data protection?

Data protection means using personal information in a fair, proper and transparent manner. Data protection laws across the world safeguard individuals’ personal information (or “personal data”). In particular, by ensuring that appropriate data security measures are in place to keep personal data secure and by recognising that individuals have rights over how their personal data is used.

What is personal data?

Personal data means any information relating to an individual. Obvious types of personal data include things like names and email addresses, but it includes less obvious types of information – such as online identifiers. The law also recognises and grants additional protection to information that is particularly sensitive and may pose a risk to individuals (religious beliefs, racial or ethnic, political opinions, health information, genetic and biometric data, sex life and sexual orientation, and financial information).

Although at Unilever we are dedicated to issues that often seem political, such as causes relating to human rights and the environment, we don’t get involved in party politics.

Unilever companies do not support or donate to any political candidates or parties.

As a result, you are only allowed to support a political candidate or party in a personal capacity, not in your role as an employee.

Communications with investment communities, including shareholders, brokers, analysts and the media, have important legal requirements and demand specialist skills and experience.

Because of this, all communication with investment communities and the media must be managed carefully.
